Port Arthur, Ont.,
January 23, 1945.

Indian Affairs Br., Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

With reference to school repairs in the agency, authorized under your letters of September 1st, files, 9-13-5, 9-9-5, 9-7-5 and 9-14-5, I would be pleased if the Department would forward a further advance of $100.00, to complete the work in this connection.

Paylists covering the balance of the first advance will be forwarded in a few days time.

J. G. Burk, Indian Agent.

| CHEQUE No. | IN FAVOUR OF | AMOUNT |
|------------|--------------|--------|

Send cheque to:

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.

April 17, 1945.

Indian Affairs Br., Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

I have a request from the teacher of the Mission Bay Indian day school, for the following articles:

2 Mops and pails
2 Pails
2 lids
5 lbs wax
1 gal. glo-coat

The cost of purchasing the above will be $13.25 and I would be pleased if the Department would authorize same.

J. G. Burk, Indian Agent.
Ottawa, April 20, 1945.

Mr. J. G. Burk, Indian Agent, Port Arthur, Ont.

With reference to your letter of the 17th instant, you may purchase the following articles for use at the Mission Bay Indian Day School:

- 2 mops and pails,
- 2 pails
- 2 lids
- 5 lbs. wax
- 1 gallon Glo-coat.

It is noted that the cost will be $13.25.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Philip Phelan,

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 11th instant, No. 163/9, enclosing an extract from a letter addressed to you by Miss Louisa Lyke, teacher of the Mississauga School, in which that lady states that it has always been the custom to allow white children to attend that school on their paying a fee of fifty cents a month each; that the children of Mrs. George Sayer have been attending for 16 months, but Mrs. Sayer refuses to pay anything for them.

Your letter with cheque enclosed safely received. Many thanks for having consulted with my advice in such an emergency. Can you any idea where your humble servant is situated? I am in the wilds of Wigwamoa by the side of a road leading to a number of Indians who came which was but a few miles distant. It is quite common to see twenty-five and thirty men go by late and early intoxicated and so far, some so much the further that they do get into anything of drinking from a bottle almost inside of the school door. On two occasions three men at one time and two at another remained around the school, wrestling for some time, after in this condition they call at my door something to eat.
Once since I have been here I was obliged to fire two shots from my window almost at midnight — A hoarse, abysmal sound came up to my door and there knocked harshly several times — I sat there ready to collapse with fear — then I picked up courage went to the window and fired two shots — The rascal never spoke while he was knocking, the lamp was burning and he stood in the light outside plainly through the cracks of the door and at the same time if he had known it a quarter inch would have opened the door as there was nothing holding it but two short screws in a ten or fifteen cent lock — the night itself would scare you, it being dark as dungeon, snowing, blowing, raining etc., For this reason I was, and am, I might say all the time about scared to death, living alone in such an isolated place behind such poor locks etc. Where, if the door and windows were open and our house would not almost die of fear when they would knock which is quite often — After enduring that awful midnight fright I sought for another side door, two strong bolts, two cases of dynamite and four locks on the two windows — Recently I have had shutters made for my windows, to let out

Secretary Dept. Indian Affairs

Sir,

I have been disappointed in my expectations. I presume the early breakup had something to do with it, whether mid-day meal and the simple garments.

Most of the Indians with their wives and families left here on the A.M. of the 14th, for what I supposed to be an absence of two months or thereabouts. To my great surprise they all returned on the 22nd, and today the school is full of children. I have all arrangements made to take this care for them, my disappointment is little imagined than described.

Since January 1909, school has been in operation without taking any holidays. For the last six months, I taught Saturday and holidays, Sundays and holidays, so the former I taught for the sake of the children, in the latter I had religious instruction.

Today, I was speaking to the Chief, he told me they were all going away again but he thought most of the women would remain at home with the children so that they could attend school.

On the 3rd and 10th, a number of the pupils made their first Communion; they did it so neatly that it has made a great impression upon the parents. At all times the Indians think a great deal more of their church than the school.

Dear Sirs;

Mrs. John Dyke of Mississaga is here on behalf of the Indians on the Mississaga Reserve.

She states that they are not at all satisfied with the teacher, Miss Annie Kehoe, who is at present occupying the position of teacher at the Mississaga Reserve. They have complained to the Indian Agent here, Mr. Samuel Hagen, but fear that the Agent could not have reported to you as they received no reply and nothing has been done.

In the first instance this young lady is receiving $100.00 to feed the Indian children, while the Indians are quite able and willing to feed their own children and would much prefer to do so. As a matter of fact she has not been doing it and has been receiving the $100.00 for nothing.

They also complain that this teacher has not been doing her duty towards the children in not keeping the school open during the time of year when all regular schools are running. It seems that she closes the school and goes away on holidays whenever it pleases her. There were other times that the teacher was engaged with other parties in the school, during school hours, and had the door locked so that the children could not get in and they were exposed to the cold.

There are a great many other complaints and the
I. Dept.

Indians ask that this teacher be removed. They have requested Mrs. Dyke to intervene on their behalf.

Mrs. Dyke is well known to some of the members of your Department. Mr. Campbell and Mr. Chittie, the timber inspector are both acquainted with Mrs. Dyke. She is a lady who has the respect of the whole community and has always taken a deep interest in the affairs of the Indian on the Mississaga Reserve. They go to her with all their troubles, and for that reason she has come to me on their behalf, requesting me to write you and place the matter before you.

There seems to be some friction between the Indians and the Missionary, the Rev. Father Richards, over the school teacher. They have asked the Reverend gentleman to have her removed but it appears that he wants her to stay.

At present there is a very strong feeling against the young lady. They say that she has been receiving money from the Department in the name of some of the Indian women, when in reality the money has been for herself, the others having nothing to do with it. They do not get the money that is provided for the scrubbing of the school and matters of this kind, in fact they have not been doing that work, and have given the young lady no authority to use their names in getting money from the department for the work done.

There are a great many complaints of this kind. In
fact it would fill a large volume; I am only reciting a few of them so that you can understand the feeling against this young lady teacher. In order to discover the truth or falsity of these statements it would be necessary to have a man on the ground to investigate. As matters stand I am afraid that this teacher's usefulness among the Indians is much retarded.

I may further say that owing to the fact that the Indians bring their complaints to Mr. & Mrs. Jno. Dyke, there is considerable friction between these people and the Indians and some very hard things have been said by the teacher against Mr. and Mrs. Dyke, which charges Mr. and Mrs. Dyke repudiate as being altogether without foundation. MEMORANDUM.

I reached Thessalon about midnight and on Sunday morning I sent word to Mr. Hagan that I was there and would like to see him. He came over in the afternoon and we arranged to leave for Mississauga on Monday noon. We took the train to Blind River where we got a horse and buggy and drove out to the Mississauga Reserve about five miles.

The school on the reserve is in charge of Miss Annie Kehoe and was in session when we arrived there. There were 8 children present, 5 boys and 3 girls. All the children were very backward in their studies, only one boy being able to read at all and the other children in the a b c class. The school-house was scrupulously clean and well equipped. The register showed that there are 33 pupils on the roll, but the attendance is very irregular and the average varied from 10 to 17 during the year.

A family named Dyke, who live on the borders of the reserve and keep a small trading post, are very bitter against Miss Kehoe, especially Mrs. Dyke, who employed a lawyer at Thessalon to write to the Department asking for her dismissal on certain stated grounds. I tried to get
at the bottom of the trouble and came to the conclusion that these charges were based on the personal dislike of Mrs. Dyke for Miss Kehoe. They are both hot headed Irish women and are very bitter against each other. Miss Kehoe is a confirmed old maid and set in her ways and does not think that Mrs. Dyke has any business to interfere with her. The Dykes have lived there for a number of years and have a good deal of influence with the Indians who deal with them and Mrs. Dyke thinks that Miss Kehoe's presence on the reserve interferes with her interests and her peace of mind and wants her removed. Miss Kehoe admitted having dickered with the Indians and I warned her to cease this practice. Mrs. Dyke said some pretty hard things about Miss Kehoe's character, but on making careful inquiries I was unable to find anyone who would substantiate her statement. Miss Kehoe and the Agent do not pull well together. Mr. Hagan is an Orangeman and Miss Kehoe is a Roman Catholic and is backed up by Father Richard and the Bishop. Miss Kehoe is not much of a teacher, but it would be a difficult matter to get a better one to live on the reserve.

As a result of my visit I do not think that the Department would be justified in dismissing her to gratify the Dykes and I think Mr. MacKay, who also visited the reserve a short time before I was there, will bear me out.
Blind River, Ont.

From January 1913 to May 1914 she spent her week ends at Mrs. Alphonse Berthelotte's at Blind River. Mrs. A. Berthellette lives now at the Hiawatha Hotel, Sault Ste Marie. And Mrs. Berthellette told me that Miss M. Goy closed her school and left for Blind River often on Friday.
morning, and sometimes as early as Thursday or even Wednesday; that very seldom she was back for her school before Monday noon, and often was back for her school only on Tuesday or Wednesday. Many times she would be a whole week away from her school. Indians told me that children who went to school on Monday morning in the winter, had to remain the whole forenoon shut out in the cold. The young man or tramp above mentioned came and spent every evening shut up in the school alone with Miss M. Goey. I saw him myself leaving the school as late as quarter to twelve at night. Indians tell me that she used to remain alone with him in the dark in her school, and wait till he would be gone to light her lamp. The young man often spent the whole day at the school, and, as the Chief remarked to me, it was then recess the whole day for the children. Mr. and Mrs. Berthelotte refused her all last admittance to their house, because Miss M. Goey would not give up keeping company till midnight with that young man. She gave dances at night in her school at least four times for young men and young girls of Blind River. In order to continue to keep...
company with that young man, she has not gone home nor taken any vacation, but has secured a position as book-keeper in a butcher's shop in Blind River.

Since I have experienced that Miss M'Coey is in the habit of lying and deceiving, and her sister, Mrs. Herbert A. Reilly, wife of the C.P.R. ticket clerk at Sault Ste Marie, told me that her sister Lillian had always the habit of lying and deceiving. I am inclined to think that Miss M'Coey may not have been overzealous in making out her quarterly reports; but of course it is impossible now to get at any data.

I was at Mississauga from the 26th to the end of the month of June, and know from personal knowledge that Miss M'Coey left her school on Friday night, the 26th, and never came back to teach, but remained in Blind River till the end of the quarter. Now for the sake of curiosity you might look at her report for the two last days of the quarter, namely Monday and Tuesday, 27th and 30th of June, 1914.

A teacher in a Catholic school should be, not only a nominal Catholic, but also a practical one, but Miss M'Coey is not. She was warned that both the Priest at Blind River and myself would refuse her the sacraments.
of the Church, unless she gave up her scandalous life.

She has no teacher's certificate for Ontario.

If she will be late trying to get another school, it will be her own fault. I notified her in time that she had to give up her school.

I remain,

Sir,

Yours truly,
J. R. Richard, S.J.
MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Last month the Rev. Father Richard, Roman Catholic Missionary in charge of the north shore of Georgian Bay, wrote the Department asking if Miss McGoey, teacher of the Mississauga Indian School, had sent in her resignation. He was informed that she had not done so. Mr. Agent Hagan wrote the Department on the 28th ultimo enclosing a letter from Miss McGoey from which it would appear that some trouble had arisen between herself and Father Richard. Mr. Hagan was told that if the Priest had any complaints to make against the teacher they should be put in writing. Father Richard has now written the Department accusing Miss McGoey of neglecting her school and making grave insinuations against her character.

Mr. Hagan in his letter above referred to says, "I am sorry to say that I do not believe a word of it. The lady in question is as good as gold. She has brought the school up from two children to nineteen and the Indians were well..."
well pleased with her work, but they are superstitious and they are afraid of the Priest. He wants the lady to send in her resignation. I do not want to lose the teacher as she is the best in my agency and as far as I can find out the stories told are a tissue of falsehoods."

In view of these conflicting statements I think the matter should be investigated in justice to the teacher.

Sir:

Dear Mrs. Phelan,

In your recent letter of December 15th, you were asking me, that, if I was finding any strong objection to Miss Mac Neally, teacher in Mississauga, to let it be known to you.

This is what I think to be said about Miss Mac Neally.

About the moral point of view, her conduct is perfect; but I will have some objection about her way of acting towards the children. She does not seem to have a very acute pedagogical and psychological sense. At my first visit, since she is back, I went as usual to school; the first very thing she did was to run down some of the pupils showing me their mistakes. I was very much surprised. On the other hand, I know positively that these same pupils were making some real efforts and doing their best.
Everything there, according to her mind was bad; the hospitals in St. Regis (where she taught) were far better. If she had told me this privately, it would have been all right, but she was saying this before everybody in class, and of course this was repeated by the children to their parents. She does not seem to know what is to encourage these Indians, what is perhaps the most important with them.

Everytime I went there she was always complaining about something; she is disgusted about the Indians; she does not want to use any food that an Indian would have touched, the comfort is not satisfactory, the government does not give her enough comfort... It is tiresome, everyone to hear her complains.

I do not think Miss Mac Nally is fit to teach in our Indian Missions, I mean the lonely places, because she is not ready enough to accept the small sacrifices, and the abnegation required by the mission life.

It is true that her health seems pretty poor, she is often complaining about her throat, and the difficulty for her to teach and talk. Nevertheless, about what she told me, even when she was suffering from her throat, she continued to teach.

I heard a few Indians telling their desire...
to have another teacher; especially for this reason of not encouraging the children, and too easily saying here and there what she is thinking unfavorably about such a one or such another one.

They would be pleased to have again Miss McKitchen coming back; she was very popular, though most likely she had not the same value in science as Miss MacKainty. She was also able to make the children think sing. The little concert she had for Christmas time made a good impression on the Indians. She was certainly encouraging the children who were pleased to come to school.

Another school teacher, Miss Meadigan from Blind River told me also her desire to teach in Mississauga. The advantage would be perhaps that every week she would be able to go home. She is now teaching in Sprague and I think she is succeeding well. Having Miss Meadigan in Mississauga so close to Blind River, where her family is living, would give a certain guarantee for the moral...
This is dear Mrs. Kelan, what I might say about Miss Mac Nealy: her moral conduct seems to be perfect, but she is not fit for the teaching among the Indians, at least in the small missions, not encouraging them too particular, too difficult to please, wanting too much comfort...

It may happen that the school teacher in Batchewana leaves. Miss Sloane (or Sloan) who was teaching formerly in Saginaw, then in Bauteau and now living in West Bay (Montreal Island) waiting for a place, would be perhaps good for this mission.

Excuse me, dear Mrs. Kelan, to take so much of your time. Pray for Lord, to give you His Blessing and to help you in your important work.

Religiously Yours in Christ,

Father Paul Rind'homme, S.J.

Dear Mr. MacKenzie:

I had heard from some parties of the exaggerated precautions adopted by the teacher of the Indian School of Mississauga. I have heard also that her practices and manners tend to antagonize the Indians. To assure myself of the truth of the complaints, I communicated with the Inspector who visits that school. I enclose your his reply — he evidently considers her tactics and attitude abnormal.

Any one who knows the Indians will understand that a teacher in order to be efficient in her work must first win the affection of the pupils. She will get nowhere with them if she antagonizes them.

I think it would be advisable to let Miss McNulty go at the end of the school year and get another. Having a Normal School in North Bay many of our local girls obtain teaching certificates — and so there is a surplus of teachers.

Dear Sir:

Re. Mississauga,

It may happen that the question be already settled about the school teacher in Mississauga, it may happen also that it is not, and it is with this hope that I am bringing a few details which may help in the decision.

I was in Mississauga these days, the first time since the school is over, and I had the visit of some of the Indian parents complaining about the school teacher.

It seems that Miss MacBulby was surpassing her rights towards the children. Quite often, told me the parents, she was keeping the children late, sometimes until six o'clock in the evening, and sometimes also making them coming one hour before the school opens in the morning.
For some of the children leaving far, especially in winter time, it is too hard. Myself, when I was coming to the mission, I was surprised to see the children leaving so late from school; nevertheless, I never said anything, estimating that there was a reason for it. But when this thing occurs too often, the sufficient reason is not more here.

I wonder also, if it is a good pedagogical counsel to tell the children, and forbid them to say anything to their parents of what she had said in school; and saying also to the children, that there is no use for their parents to come and see her, that she will not accept any complaint from them. The result is that some of the children have less respect for their parents, and more incline not to listen to them.

The parents came and asked me, if there will not be any possibility for their children to be accepted in Spanish. Of course, I answered them that this was impossible, because they were leaving close to the school, but this is an indication of the spirit of discontentment which exists among the people.

I certainly insist that Miss McReilly be changed. She is just making herself be feared by the children; they submit because they are afraid of her, but they do not like her, and the general impression is that she should be changed.
The children have no courage at work, too often she is too stern, and too severe. She is most likely a very good school-teacher for a city-school, but for a small country school, or a mission, she is not of that type that will make a good work. She has not only to teach the children, but she has also to form their character and to educate them. She is not encouraging the children, and too many times she said openly that she was despising the children. This makes the work very hard for the missionary. I am afraid to put myself in cause, this being able to make my testimony of smaller value, but I am obliged to say that I found that there is no cooperation possible with Miss McReilly. I would have difficulties with the six or seven other school-teachers I have in my missions, I would say that it is due to myself, but I must admit that in all the other places I am getting along fine with the school-teachers, and that we are able to do some good work for the children.

In Mississauga, it is the contrary that happens; when I suggested something, I mean in my line, church or teaching of religion, I never interfered with anything in school—Miss McReilly did the contrary of what I was asking her. In the small missions, we need the help of the school—
teacher, if we want to be able to do some good work in Mississauga for two years, we lost our time.

I must make an exception for the three months Miss McKitchen was teaching. Of course, because young, Miss McReilly despised her, and said that she was no good; but the facts and results were there; the children were more encouraged, more pleased, and more ready to do something; she had the talent to make them work, and like their work... I could add also that her talent as a musician, playing and singing, made her be in favour. We have also that other testimony, that when Miss McKitchen left, most of the children went to the station, 3 miles distant, to greet her and tell her they were sorry to see her leaving...

They would not do it for Miss McReilly. During the time Miss McKitchen was there, there was certainly an atmosphere of release, contentment, and peace.

I wish earnestly that we could have her coming back to Mississauga, it is the general wish among parents and children. She was teaching this year in Penetanguishene, but I know, that anytime we will need her, she will be ready to come again and teach in our missions... She understands the teaching more under that idea to devote herself for the good of the poor children than of a way to make a living, and have in the same time an easy life.

Miss McReilly does not want to admit any fault in herself, she seems to have the persuasion that she is perfect finished in every detail. Indignant, and very set in her ways and ideas, queer also, she is contrary...
As I am writing to you, Honan, I will take the opportunity to recommend Miss Cozy, for the school of Gerald Bay; as far as I know, and about what Mr. J. Smith, our Indian Agent for that district, told me, she should be able to do a very good work. It is also the opinion of Mr. Greening, and of our Bishop, Pape, Scotland.

We were all sorry that Miss Duff decided to leave, because during the four years she was in that hard mission, she did a very good work, and was well liked; but as she is leaving to settle definitely for life for better, we can only approve her...

Thanking you in advance for the interest you will take in this matter, I beg your Honour to accept my regards.

Yours truly in Christ,
Father Paul Pond, honman, S.J.,

Memorandum:

THE HONOURABLE THE SUPERINTENDENT GENERAL,

Since September 1st, 1932, Miss M. MacNulty has been teaching at the Mississauga River Indian Day School, Reserve No. 5, Electoral District of Algoma East.

For several years, Miss MacNulty was teaching at the St. Regis Village Indian Day School and, while the reports received indicated that she had good teaching ability, the Department found it necessary to dispense with her services at the St. Regis Village School at the end of June, 1931, owing to the fact that she was unable to live harmoniously with the other teachers.

She was re-engaged in 1932 as teacher of the Mississauga River School.

Separate School Inspector Maurice inspected the Mississauga River School on May 16th, last, and reported as follows:

"The pupils have progressed very much since the last year in all the subjects of the course of study. The teacher has given the pupils systematic training in all the subjects with success.

"Although the pupils in charge of Miss MacNulty have been progressing this year, it may be..."
be advisable to transfer the teacher to another school if at all possible on account of the misunderstanding between the teacher, the parish priest and the Indians.

"The missionary in charge of the Mississauga Mission has been in my office several times complaining about the teacher on matters not pertaining to her teaching. It seems that the Indians are not satisfied with her on account of this misunderstanding between the missionary and the teacher."

The local missionary, Rev. P. Prud'homme, S. J., wrote the Department recently, stating that Miss MacNulty's services were unsatisfactory both to him and to the Indians.

I am now in receipt of a letter from Rt. Rev. D. J. Scollard, Bishop of Sault Ste. Marie, in which he states that, owing to Miss MacNulty's peculiar disposition, her services are most unsatisfactory and His Lordship, therefore, requests that we dispense with her services.

You will note from the first part of this memorandum that reports received show that Miss MacNulty has good teaching methods. At the same time, from our previous experience with Miss MacNulty at the St. Regis Village School, the Department understands the reasons for the present complaints regarding her.

I should appreciate your direction in this matter in order that a reply may be made to His Lordship Bishop Scollard.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General.

I wish to refer to memorandum of August 16th last, regarding the request made by the late Right Rev. D. J. Scollard, Bishop of Sault Ste. Marie, that the services of Miss M. MacNulty, teacher of the Mississauga River Indian Day School (Reserve No. 8, Electoral District of Algoma East), be dispensed with, owing to certain friction which had developed between herself and the local Catholic Missionary on the Reserve. At that time, you instructed that Miss MacNulty's services be retained for the term ending the 31st instant, and that the matter be again submitted for your consideration.

Owing to the death of His Lordship Bishop Scollard, no further action was taken.

Miss MacNulty has been in the employ of the Department for several years. Both the public school inspector and the local Indian Agent have invariably reported her teaching services to be satisfactory. The only complaint that has been made against her is lack of tact in her dealings with the Indian parents, and the complaint of the Roman Catholic Missionary, unrelated to her teaching service.

In fairness to Miss MacNulty, it should be stated that the disagreement between herself and the local Missionary is not entirely one-sided. The Missionary is aggressive, and, during his visits to the school and reserve, Miss MacNulty has considered that his instructions, which practically amount to a demand, are not always in the interests of the classroom work.

I would submit for consideration that, as no recent complaints have been received regarding Miss MacNulty, and also in view of her lengthy and satisfactory service, that she be continued as teacher, at least for the balance of the present school year ending June 30th, 1935.

Deputy Superintendent General.

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

I beg to refer to memoranda of August 16th and December 24th, 1934, regarding the services of Miss M. MacNulty, teacher of the Mississauga River Indian Day School (Reserve No. 8 - Electoral District of Algoma East).

The late Right Reverend D. Scollard, Bishop of Sault Ste. Marie, requested that Miss MacNulty's services be dispensed with, owing to her inability to work in harmony with the local Catholic missionary on the reserve. You approved of her services being continued as teacher for the balance of the present school year, ending June 30th, 1935.

I may say that there have been no recent complaints. Her work in the classroom is satisfactory and the pupils under her charge have made progress. This is a rather difficult situation to deal with, in fairness to Miss MacNulty, against whose teaching services there has been no complaint. The principal reason for requesting her dismissal was her lack of tact in her dealings with the Indian parents and the local Catholic missionary.

I am submitting this case for your consideration and direction as to whether Miss MacNulty should be given notice that her services will not be required after June 30th, next, the end of the present school year, or whether her services be retained for a further period.

Thank you for your favour of July 27th. I have not answered it up to now because I have been able to find no trace of a suitable teacher for the Mississauga school. Dear Father McKey:

I have your letter of the 7th instant, with reference to securing a teacher for the Mississauga School. I do not think it would be advisable to consider Mrs. Pelletier.

I also regret to say that I do not think we can secure any priority for a telephone. As a matter of fact, I feel that if you could get in touch with the District Manager of the Bell Telephone Company you would have as much chance as we have of having them place a phone near the school. The Department would not be in a position to bear any of the cost, as we do not supply phones to Indian day schools.

I tried to secure Miss Christine Wakegijig who applied for a school, but by the time my answer reached her she had secured another situation. 9. "Self-contained Domestic Establishment" means a dwelling house, apartment or other similar place of residence, containing at least two bedrooms, in which residence amongst other things the taxpayer as a general rule sleeps and has his meals prepared and served.

10. Effect of Failure to File Form T.D.1 (Revised January 1946). In cases where Form T.D.1 (Revised January 1946) is not completed and filed with the employer deductions from the salaries or wages paid each after January 1st, 1946 must be made as if the employee were a single person without dependents even though the employee may have filed a previous Form T.D.1. Single persons without dependents need not file this form.

11. Change in Status or Dependents—If during the year any change occurs in the status of dependents of an employee, the employee must complete and file with his employer an amended Form T.D.1. A change in status will affect the Allowance cheque should not call for an amended T.D.1 Form unless the change is in excess of $1.00 per month. See Item 19 for information regarding effect of changes on deductions during the currency of the year.

12. If Employee Has More Than One Employer, it will be necessary to complete and file Form T.D.1 with each employer, to claim married status or dependents.

13. Filing of Income Tax Return. In addition to filing this form you must file your Income Tax Return Form T.1 Special or T.1 General for the calendar year on or before 30th April of the following year.

14. Family Allowances rates—

For each child under 6 years of age, $5.00 per month
For each child 6 or over but under 10, $6.00 per month
For each child 10 or over but under 13, $7.00 per month
For each child 13 or over but under 16, $8.00 per month

Less reductions in monthly allowances—

For the fifth child—$1
For the sixth and seventh child—$2 each
For the eighth and each additional child—$3 each

INSTRUCTIONS TO THE EMPLOYER

15. If Form T.D.1 (Revised January 1946) Not Filed By Employee. Any employee who fails to file a completed Form T.D.1. (Revised January 1946) must be regarded for tax deduction purposes as a single person without dependents.

16. Employer's Disallow Claim for Excessive Number of Dependents. To be entitled to the full tax credits for a dependent other than the taxpayer's own children or grandchildren (or any other dependents in Item 8 (1) above), a taxpayer must contribute at least $400 annually to the support of such dependent. Many persons are unaware of this limitation. For tax deduction purposes, employers will make deductions from the salary or wages of an employee who claims more than two dependents in Item 5 as if the employee had only two dependents in addition to his own children or grand-children (or children as defined in Item 8 (1) above). The employer will notify the employee that he must submit proof of any claim for more dependents to the District Inspector of Income Tax. If the employee proves to the satisfaction of the Inspector that he is entitled to further allowances, the employee will be advised accordingly.

17. Employer to Scrutinize Claims by Single Persons for Married Status. The definition of a "Self-contained Domestic Establishment" contained in Item 9 indicates clearly that a taxpayer is not entitled to claim Married Status by reason of supporting a dependent therein unless the dependent actually resides with the taxpayer. Therefore, employers are instructed to check the address shown under "Married Status" against the actual address in Item 2 (which should show where he is actually living at the time of making the declaration) and in every case where the addresses are not identical the employer must make deductions as if the taxpayer were a single person, with or without dependents as the case may be.

18. Employer's Responsibility Regarding Form T.D.1. The employer will have regard to the instructions contained in Items 16 and 17 above and will otherwise complete and file Form T.D.1 only completed. If any employee shows children under 16 years of age as dependents under Items 4 or 5, he must also complete Item 6 or the employer shall not take account of such dependents under 16 years of age for tax deduction purposes. He will also delete as a dependent under Item 5 the name of any person whom the employee has already listed in Item 4 unless the claim for married status came within paragraph (C) thereof. If the employer has reason to believe that the information on this form is incorrect or false, he will not act upon the information until the employee has made the appropriate confirmation or correction. In case of doubt, the matter should be referred to the District Inspector of Income Tax.

19. Action on Receipt of Amended Form T.D.1 During Currency of Year. Employers are required to file an amended Form T.D.1 if any change occurs in status or dependents. The employer should give immediate effect to a change from "Single status" to "Married status", or an increase in the number of dependents and to any substantial change (i.e. in excess of $1.00 per month) in the Family Allowance cheque. A change from "Married status" to "Single status" (e.g. where the employee becomes a widow) should not be made effective until the first pay period in the next calendar year because the employee will still be entitled to claim Married status for the whole of the calendar year in which the event took place. Similarly, a decrease in the number of dependents should not generally require a change in the deductions until the following calendar year with one important exception due to the provision that a taxpayer may not claim as a dependent any person who has an income in excess of $400 during the calendar year. If, for example, a son who was previously claimed as a dependent under Item 5 is claimed as a dependent on Form T.D.1 takes up employment from which he will earn over $400 during the calendar year, immediate effect should be given to the amended form T.D.1 as otherwise the employee will be left with a substantial balance of tax to pay with his return on Form T.1 Special or T.1 General.

20. Further Information or Forms with respect to deduction of tax may be obtained from any District Inspector of Income Tax.

21. Completed Forms T.D.1 must be kept on file by the employer in order that they may be available at all times for payroll inspection by officers of the Taxation Division.

35-Year-Old Blind River School Burns

(Special to The Star)

BLIND RIVER.—The Mississaugas School on the Indian Reservation about three and a half miles from here was burned to the ground early this morning.

The fire started when an oil lamp, accidentally hit by the teacher, Paul Berthelot, exploded. Mr. Berthelot had just returned to the school where he resided and had just lit the lamp when the accident occurred.

He was knocked unconscious for a while. The fire was noticed by Father McKay from the church nearby. He and a group of reserve residents rescued Mr. Berthelot and managed to save some of the newer desks and the stove.

The one room frame structure was about 35 years old. Approximately 40 pupils are enrolled at the school. Mr. Berthelot, who is the second son of the town mayor, Louis Berthelot, had only been teaching at the school since Christmas. His living quarters were at the rear of the school.

Ottawa, February 9, 1948.

Memorandum:

Classroom Inspection Report -
Mississauga Indian Day School.

I visited this school on February 4th. The teacher is Mr. Godin, age 37 years with a Second Class Certificate and twelve years experience.

This school was being conducted in the Roman Catholic Church while waiting the completion of the new school. Due to the enrolment of thirty-eight it was being run in two groups; the Juniors in the morning; the Seniors in the afternoon. Due to the very cold weather, only twelve were present when I inspected.

I found these children poor at following directions. It was evident that they had received too much individual attention and could not work well on their own. I advised Mr. Godin to make more use of workbooks and textbooks and to place more responsibility on his pupils. They seem slow and lethargic and are making fair progress only. In Arithmetic fundamentals I found them quite weak and their Spelling was only fair. Mr. Godin speaks good English and maintains easy discipline. I later discussed with Mr. Godin his intentions for next year. He is writing a High School Teachers' Certificate Examinations in May and if he passes, intends to attempt to get a position at the High School in Blind River. He was advised to inform the Department immediately he receives definite word concerning this examination. He would be a satisfactory teacher, but seems to lack self-confidence and apparently the Agent agreed with me in thinking that he lacks initiative.
Mr. Buck, the Chief Architect was inspecting the new school while I was with Mr. Godin. I later visited the new building and found it entirely satisfactory. I agreed with Mr. Buck that we have a good building, well constructed and well lighted. It should give many years' service. I was very pleased with the classroom and in particular with the lighting from the windows.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Ottawa, July 2nd, 1924.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 27th instant, regarding the request made by Miss L. Addey, teacher of the Sagamook Indian Day School, to be transferred to the Mississauga River Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that the department would have no objection to this transfer, and will allow Miss Addey salary at the same rate as she received as teacher of the Sagamook School, viz: $700 per annum, supplemented by the bonus provided by law. Payment of salary and bonus to be based on ten teaching months in the year. You will be good enough to inform her of the Department's approval of her transfer to the Mississauga School for the next school year, and arrange with her to take up duties when the school re-opens after the summer holidays, on or about September 2nd, next.

Kindly inform the Department as to whether Miss Addey accepts this transfer or not.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

C. F. Rothera, Esq.,

Sir,

I am very sorry I had to go One Dollar and ninety-five cents more than I receive for rice, but I could not possibly do any better. I only got half a lot of flannelette and am going out tomorrow, knitting and sewing needles and all.

On Monday Paul Boyer cleared the dyke and hung the storm door, therefore, I could not make school.

On Tuesday I began the mid-day meal with fourteen pupils which they ate so voraciously that I spared in three days I would not have any provisions on hand. On Wednesday the same atypical crowd came again with the usual articles—Thursday, even worse—today I gave rice and milk, with the other articles, even pupils present.

Tuesday and Wednesday were very stormy days (the snow was thick) some of the pupils who had scarcely been out a door all pointer contracted severe colds and are today real sick.
Since the mid-day meal began the children are always on time in the morning before they seldom if ever were—sleeping late was the rule.

The Indians are delighted with the new plan; those living at a distance are talking of moving nearer to the school. Mr. Penny will bring my supplies, and the action for the mid-day meal at the school, a distance of four miles, as a rule, I always had to carry.

March 8, 1912

Dear Sir:- No. 151703-5.

Messrs. Solomon Bros. have handed me your letters of March 30th, 1911, September 7th and 14th, 1911 and have asked me to attend to this matter for them. It appears that they should have received the cheque for $3.10, in payment of the account of Solomon Bros. & T. Shamess and this cheque has never been received.

I might say that Solomon Bros. bought out the interest of T. Shamess in the business formerly conducted by Solomon Bros. & T. Shamess, so that Solomon Bros. are the proper parties to receive payment and have the authority to endorse the cheque. As this matter has been outstanding for such a long time, I would be very glad if you would take it up and issue a duplicate cheque, because the first cheque has apparently been mislaid by Mr. S. Hagan, your Indian Agent at Thessalon, Ontario. Had it been paid, you would have received it long ago.

Awaiting your reply, I remain,

Yours very truly,

Ottawa, 21st March, 1918.

Sir:-

With reference to your letter of the 15th instant, and previous correspondence regarding official cheque No. 2466 drawn in favour of Messrs. Solomon Bros., which cheque you received and undertook to forward to them; I beg to say that in view of the fact that you did not personally send the letter which contained the cheque, you are in a measure responsible for its loss, and the Department considers that you should furnish a bond of indemnity, which will permit of the issue of a duplicate cheque. I enclose herewith a form of Bond of Indemnity which you should execute and return to the Department. If it is found satisfactory, a duplicate cheque will be sent to Messrs. Solomon Bros. Had the firm named received the cheque and lost it, they would have been required to furnish a bond before a duplicate could issue. It is fortunate that the amount of the cheque is not large.

In future you should register all letters containing cheques, and in the event of loss they can be traced.

With reference to the bond, I beg to say that it is customary to have three names furnished therein, but as the cheque is small it will be sufficient if you execute the bond with sureties.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

S. Hagan Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Thessalon, Ont.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 14th instant in reference to the purchase of prizes for the children attending the schools in your agency.

In reply I beg to say that within a few months back prizes were furnished for the Sagamook, Serpent River and Thessalon schools. It is not the practice of the Department to furnish prizes more than once a year and these schools cannot be now considered. You may, however, expend a sum not exceeding $5.00 in the purchase of prizes for the children attending the Mississauga School. The account should show in detail the articles purchased with prices.

I beg leave to report that the well we dug at Bissessauga a short time ago has gone dry when we quit the well there was three feet of water in it running through a bed of gravel lovely water, when the Teacher came back the well was dry and the old spring where we used to get the water was dry as well and the Teacher had to go about a mile for water. I sent the well dug down and he dug it three feet deep and got splendid water, it came in so fast they could not bail it out and he put 3 feet of cement in it and a piece more to the rim and we thought there was water enough to a whole farm and the Teacher has just called me by phone and says the water has dried up and the well is dry but there is not a drop of water within nearly a mile of the school what would you advise us to do we must have water it is a very strange thing, I might mention that a farmer about 6 miles from this farm had a well that acted like this one and he put cement in the bottom and that held the water so he has no more trouble.

I beg leave to draw your attention to the matter of the well at Minissauga Indian School on Minissauga Indian Reserve when we dug the well last spring it was a beautiful well clear spring water and was all right when the teacher left for vacation when he returned the well was dry and none to be found in the vicinity of the school it was a puzzling and I sent the well digger down to see what was wrong he said the well was dry I gave orders for him to dig it deeper which he did he dug it three feet deeper and got a fine supply of water he put down a culvert and attached a piece of pipe to the pump and a short time after he came home the well went dry again I was informed that there was a quarry a few miles away that had a well acted the same as ours and put cement in the bottom and it was all right in a recent letter you told me to find out the cost of cement I went to the farmer and found it was a falsehood he never had such a well I enquired of quite a number of people and they all say we must go deeper if we were through the strata of gravel we would be all right with your permission I will have it made deeper the school is using very bad water.

Dear Sir,

Owing to lack of water I fear I shan't be able to keep school open during the severe winter weather. Since the Pump went out of order in October, water was obtained from a spring about a quarter of a mile from the School. As the snow is deep and there is no road, it is impossible to carry water from there now.

On Jan. 4th George Boyce undertook to repair the Pump and on sounding the well found it dry hence there will be no water from that source for some time.

Under present disadvantageous conditions kindly advise what I had better do.

Wishing you a very happy New Year I am,

Most respectfully Yours,

Jean M. Wainwright.
Sir,

Am enclosing a letter I received from Miss M. Dequartt Rockburgh Mississaugas River school.

The pump has gone dry to the spring wheel in a little distance from the school is too far for the teacher to carry water from.

Right now that owing to the want of rain both authorities the wells in their vicinity are only water or nearly so. Kindly advise if the school will be closed owing to this condition of affairs.

Have written the chief of field and if there is any possible chance of getting water nearer the school this place where I am in the fall am afraid there will not be.

Your obedient servant

E. Rothera.
Ottawa, January 25, 1924.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 23rd instant, enclosing a communication which you received from Miss Jean McDermott, teacher of the Mississauga River Indian Day School, relative to the water supply.

In reply I beg to say that the difficulty of obtaining water for the teacher's use is noted. You should arrange, if possible, to have an Indian or some other person draw the water required from a nearby source in a barrel. If it is necessary to do so, you may purchase a suitable barrel, and arrange to have the water required delivered at the teacher's residence as and when required. You should endeavour to have this service performed at the lowest possible cost, and it should only be continued until such time as there is a supply of water in the well, or until the teacher can obtain the quantity required herself from the spring which is situated about a quarter of a mile from the school.

I shall be pleased to hear as to whether you have been able to arrange with an Indian or some other person to draw the water required for the teacher's use, and the amount that will be charged for the service. Kindly give this matter your early attention, so that the school will not be closed.

You may forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the cost of drawing the water required for the teacher's use.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

C. F. Rothera, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Thessalon, Ont.
Sir,

In reply to letter of Jan 24th, I beg to state that I have visited the said school at Assiniboia River and have arranged to have water drawn to the school when needed. Could not obtain a barrel so bought a large tea pail used by lumberman holding about 6 gallons of water with a lid to keep the water pure.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:-

The Separate School Inspector in a report on his recent inspection of the Mississauga Indian Day School has drawn attention to the condition of the water supply. He states as follows:

"The well water is worse than ever. It is most dangerous. It seems that this has been the second attempt to get good water and it seems a failure. The water is only 9 ft. from the ground in the well. Depth only would give good water. At present the teacher and pupils use water from spring ¼ mile away."

Please furnish a report as to what you would advise be done in order to improve the condition of the well in order to provide a supply of good water. You should also furnish an estimate of the cost of any work you would advise be undertaken. This matter should receive your earliest attention.

Sir,

In answer to letter of Oct 2 nd

I beg to state that during the summer I had a couple of men digging a well but could not obtain water so had the present well bailed out & deepened & put in gravel and gravel in the bottom. On my last visit in September examined same & found the color of the water a little brown but the taste was all right. Might say that the old well where we have a pump wheel I had cleaned out a year ago is practically dry and most of the wells in this vicinity are very low owing to the dry spell of this last year.

The only thing I can see is to use the well water for washing & do as we did last year have some person carry water for drinking purposes.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6143, File 409-5, part 2)
Ottawa, April 30th, 1926.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Mississauga Indian Day School, states that the toilets require attention and that the house section of the building needs reshingling, as there is a leakage into the kitchen and bedroom. He also states that the steps at the entrance to the school are old and broken and should be repaired, and he further suggests that the kitchen and bedroom be repapered.

I have to request that you will furnish a report regarding the repairs referred to by the Inspector, stating whether you would recommend that they be carried out or not. If so, you should furnish full particulars as to the repairs you would recommend be done, and the approximate cost of same, including material and labour. Your early reply giving this information should be furnished after you have had an opportunity of visiting this school, and, if it is decided to carry out any repairs, they could be performed during the coming summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Dear Sir,

Is there any possibility of having a garage built here this spring? I have just bought a new car and I don't like the idea of leaving it exposed to the outside in the spring rain. Also, we don't have any room inside when the wood is wet and besides, the cold air gets into the garage. My dear car was stolen last year from here and I would like to have it back. But I think it's better to have it inside where you could consider buying the new building built.

The undersigned has signed
since holidays until the exception of Mr. Boyce. She spent the whole time in bed. I secured the Cod Liver Oil, and the children needed it badly. I thought I'd just have take it there in my sickness around here, but I know if not in Bird River she could save 5 months at quite a cost.

I'm sure you will be able to make the journey. I told Mr. Boyce if you do succeed in getting permission to have the bull. I would suggest that you try for 3rd Grade but if you can't he would do the job in cheaper and satisfactory way any one I know of.

Hoping you are.

Sincerely Yours,

M. A. MacLennan

Sir,

Miss MacNulty, teacher of the Mississauga River Indian Day School, visited the Department today and states that it will be impossible to heat the teacher's living quarters with wood and requests the Department to supply a Quebec heater and two tons of coal. As far as the Department is aware, wood has always been used at this school and no previous complaints have been made. Please let me know if you consider it necessary to purchase a new stove and coal. If so, you should furnish an estimate of the cost of both.

Miss MacNulty also complains that the water has to be secured from a well about a quarter of a mile from the school. Please advise where the previous teacher obtained her drinking water and whether or not it is possible to secure same closer to the school than the distance mentioned.

Miss MacNulty states that there is no lavatory at the teacher's residence. Please advise what it would cost to erect one.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

C. F. Rothera, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Thessalon, Ont.
Dear Sir,

In reply to letter of December 20th in regards to the heating of the teacher's living quarters at Mississauga River school might say that all the teachers that have taught for the last ten years have found it comfortable, and would not recommend a purchase of a coal stove. Miss McNulty was at Mississauga about two weeks, and found time to complain about everything, and not like she had been accustomed to, at the former school, having I understand living quarters with janitor to look after the teachers wants. In regards to the well, it is near the school and has been cleaned and it is ready for use. All the requirements sufficient for a school are at Mississauga, and it was only last year that the Department made alterations in the living quarters, making them more homelike for the teacher.

The attendance of white children at the school last was 12 and expect they will be the same after Xmas. Understand that Miss McNulty is not going to teach the white children, that is the report I got on my last visit to the school before the holidays.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of the following letter from the teacher of the Mississaga Indian Day School:

"I feel it my duty to report the following:

"Painting

"The school, only, was painted. All outbuildings need paint badly. The Indian in charge of the job took home two gallons of paint and the brushes. I made it a point to see him on my arrival and he promised to finish, but so far has not done so. The money granted was supposed to cover the job. I believe he is paid in full. I spoke to Mr. Sims and there it stands. Could you do something about having it finished before the cold sets in?

"Well

"I advised Mr. Rothera not to have the well finished as it was only surface water we were getting. In my absence they completed it and as it stands we cannot use the water. I believe something could be done about the source of the water, which may make it fit for use. I would be glad if both of the above could be rectified to the satisfaction of all concerned."

No doubt you will be visiting this school in the near future and you should look into the matter mentioned by the teacher and advise the Department what you consider should be done.

Yours truly,

October 28th, 1939.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of October 16th, 36-1-5, I beg to state that I have written to Dan Boyer who is at present in the woods, to ask him to hand over to Miss MacNulty, the teacher at the Mississauga Indian day school, the two gallons of paint which he was supposed to have received from the late agent, Mr. Sims, to paint the school out-houses.

To date, I have been unable to find out from the records in this office, if Boyer was paid for this job or not. At any rate, the season is too far advanced now, to do this work this year.

The wood shed at the school should be braced to keep it from collapsing. The cost of material and labour to remedy this would be approximately $10.00. The school floor should be stained and varnished. The wood work in the teacher's quarters should be painted. The cost of material and labour for this work would be approximately $35.00. The living room in the teacher's quarters requires new linoleum as the present rug is almost worn through in places. Twelve yards would be the amount of linoleum needed and the approximate cost of it would be $20.00.

These renovations should be carried out as they are really necessary.

Yours very truly,

R. P. G. Laurence,
Indian Agent.

September 16, 1940.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed herewith find Requisition for school material received from Miss MacNulty of the Mississauga Reserve Indian Day School.

Miss MacNulty asks that the porch be built on the front of her school at an approximate cost of $100.00, also that repairs to the chimney be made at a cost of approximately $15.00.

A winter porch is badly needed at this school as it is filled to capacity and very crowded. There is no place for the children to hang their overcoats, etc. Once the cold weather sets in and by adding a porch to the front of the school it would give the extra room required. This could be done at a cost of approximately $100.00 for labour and material.

I therefore recommend that, if at all possible, the chimney be repaired and the porch built.

Yours very truly,

R.P.G. Laurence
Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

On September 16 I wrote you requesting that you allow $100.00 to build a porch on the Mississauga Reserve Indian Day School, which amount was to cover material and labour. This request was granted in your letter 36-1-5, September 20.

I now find that my estimate was out considerably and that to build the porch required would at least cost $175.00, instead of $100.00. I am enclosing an estimate received from Harry H. Bell, Blind River, covering the cost of material required.

Kindly advise me if it would be possible to have the amount raised from $100.00 to $175.00 and, if so, would you please grant the necessary authority to purchase the enclosed bill of material?

Mrs. Helen Moron, teacher of the Mississauga Indian Day school has complained of the coldness, last winter, of her living quarters.

I have examined this building and made an approximate estimate of the cost of necessary improvements needed to make same comfortable.

A porch on the kitchen is needed to help keep out the snow and cold, all the windows need refitting, one new storm window, clothes closets need to be lined to keep out the cold and that part of the building which adjoins the school should be caulked and boarded up etc. The approximate cost for the above would be Material $80.00 Labour $75.00.

She has also requested that the school room be painted as it is very dark. The cost of this would be Material $18.00 Labour $30.00.

The above improvements are all necessary and I recommend that her request be granted.

Kindly advise me regarding this matter.

R. P. G. Laurence,
Indian Agent.

The teacher of the Mississauga Indian Day School complains about the coldness of the floors in her school. I have investigated her complaint and find that the school room needs a new floor. The present one is worn, full of cracks, was poorly laid down in the first place and is very draughty. I recommend that, if possible, a new floor be laid in this school.

The cost of material and labour for a new hardwood floor would be approximately $150.00. To sand and varnish same would cost approximately $100.00 more.

Kindly advise me regarding this matter at your convenience.

R. P. G. Laurence,
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

Re Mississauga School:

You are already aware that this school was burned to the ground on the morning of February 4th last. I believe also that Mr. Laurence has informed you we are making every effort to keep classes running and provide a place where they may be held.

Mr. Paul Berthelot, the Chiblows and I saved enough desks to seat all the children at present in attendance. The reading library was also saved as well as the teacher's desk and its contents. We were also able to prevent the sheds from burning, so the fire wood and coal are safe. What we did not have time to save were the children's books from the desks, although we did save some and a good many had been taken home for night lessons. However, Mr. Berthelot has managed, through friends in Blind River, to collect enough supplies for the children to be able to resume classes immediately. He has even secured the loan of a large movable blackboard.

It was suggested we try to obtain the use of Mississauga Inn as a school house. Mr. Laurence, after conferring with one of the owners in Sault Ste. Marie, tells me this is impossible for the present.

The suggestion which I am prepared to carry out immediately is the temporary loan of the church for classes until some other arrangement can be made, or until the end of the spring term. The Right Reverend Bishop Dignan has already granted verbal permission but he warned me at the same time that I must secure some guarantees from the Department that the building would not suffer from the wear and tear of classes.
Accordingly I put forward the following agreement:

The Diocese of Sault Ste. Marie freely grants the use of the Catholic Church at Mississauga for classes outside those times when the Blessed Sacrament is reserved, until such time as a more suitable place can be found, up until the end of June, 1946.

No rent will be charged for the use of building or furniture but the Department will be expected to provide the fuel for heating the premises. Moreover the Department will pay for the repair of any positive damage caused by the pupils or consequent upon the use of the building as a class room. Also the Department will make the usual allowance for scrubbing and cleaning.

Finally, if the building is used for classes for the remainder of the school year, i.e., until the end of June, 1946, the Department will pay to have the floor varnished and the interior of the church proper repainted.

I sincerely hope that the Department will accept this offer without delay.

Yours very truly

J. E. McKey, S. J.
Missionary.
Ottawa, February 12, 1946.

It was understood, of course, that we would supply the fuel required and make an allowance for janitor service. If my suggestion meets with the approval of His Excellency Bishop Dignan, you may arrange to have the school re-opened immediately. You should, of course, advise me of your acceptance, in order that I may notify the Indian Agent.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,

MEMORANDUM TO: Chiefs of Divisions,
Directors, etc.

The following letter dated August 7, 1944 from the Treasury Board has apparently never been made known to the officers of this Department. Consequently, it is requested that the information contained therein be drawn to the attention of every employee who may be in a position to be affected:

"The Treasury Board have recently had under consideration submissions from various departments recommending compensation in part or in whole to employees residing in Government premises who have suffered loss of their furniture and effects as a result of fires or other mishap at such Government premises.

After detailed consideration the Treasury Board have directed that all departments be notified that consideration cannot in the future be given to compensation of employees in such cases. The basis of this decision is that the employee should cover his risks by insurance in the same manner as other employees living in private residences are obliged to do.

Would you therefore kindly arrange that all employees of your department who may be affected shall be advised in writing of the Treasury Board's decision."

Dear Father McKey:

I have your letter of the 1st instant, with reference to the school situation at the Mississauga Reserve.

I might as well be very frank with you and state that at the present time I cannot see any prospect of erecting a new school this summer.

This particular school was destroyed by fire after we had prepared our Estimates for the fiscal year 1946-47 and, consequently, no funds were provided.

There is also an additional reason. We require a number of schools all over the Dominion. In many cases the situation is similar to that at Mississauga. In other cases the buildings are so old that they should have been replaced before this, but due to war conditions it was not possible to do so.

When preparing our appropriation for the current fiscal year, we requested funds for the erection of a number of schools throughout Canada. However, early in the present calendar year, you will remember that it was officially decided to concentrate on the erection of private homes throughout the country and, as a consequence, our public building program has been greatly curtailed. Owing to the difficulty of securing materials, we are extremely doubtful if we will be able to erect even the small number of buildings which we proposed to build.

I am sorry that I have to give you such a dismal reply, but it is simply due to conditions over which we have no control.

With kind personal regards, Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Mr. Laurence,

Pursuant to our conversation of the 6th instant re the Mississauga school, it seems good that I should set forth my opinion.

In the first place I think the fact that there will be upwards of twenty-three pupils who should be in school there next year merits our very serious attention.

Secondly, I am convinced the use of the church next year will not be practical. The arrangement has been fairly successful this year because of the fact that the teacher was a young man, and that he lived in town and could go back and forth morning and night. If the teacher were a woman, I could not allow her to use my room, even during the day. It is possible that some one might be found who would be willing to confine herself to the church proper and commute back and forth from town if taxi service were provided for her, but I am inclined to doubt this very much.

Another solution might be regular and adequate bus service to the school in Blind River. This would depend too on the accommodations of the school and the willingness of the teaching staff to stretch their resources. On this I am not prepared to say anything at present.

The only real solution is a new school immediately, and a salary for the teacher adequate to attract a good one. I know there is a housing shortage but I think everyone will agree that schools should hold an AI priority, ahead of churches and even ahead of dwellings.

If a school is begun this summer to be completed in the fall, classes could be held in the church during the warm weather until they could be moved.
into the school. It is probable that a teacher could be persuaded to put up with this inconvenience if she has the prospect of better conditions constantly before her eyes.

Hoping that these views correspond fairly closely with your own, and that they will meet with the approval of the Department,

I remain

Yours very sincerely,

J. E. [Signature]

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1947-48 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to construct a one-room Indian day school and teacher's residence at Mississauga, in the Sault Ste. Marie Indian agency, Province of Ontario;

THAT it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Mississauga Reserve;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C. 1927, provides, in part, as follows:-

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest........";

THAT efforts have been made to interest builders and contractors in the vicinity of Mississauga but the builders and contractors have advised that they could not be interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

THAT competent building contractor, namely George V. Hannah, Sault Ste. Marie, who, our officials state, is a very reliable man, has agreed to undertake the construction of the said building immediately, on the basis of cost plus a fixed fee of one thousand dollars ($1,000.);

THAT it is considered that the construction of this building is a pressing emergency and within the exception provided in Section 36 above recited, and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

Acting Minister of Mines and Resources.

It is understood that His Majesty may supply the Contractor with materials or may make available to the Contractor funds with which to purchase materials required for the purposes of this contract and any and all materials or funds so supplied or made available shall be used by the Contractor solely for the purposes of this contract.

SECTION 5.

LIST OF MATERIALS AND EQUIPMENT SUPPLIERS.

The Contractor shall, before placing any orders for any equipment or materials required for the performance of this contract submit to the Minister a list of the suppliers from which, and the prices at which it proposes to purchase such materials or equipment, and the Contractor shall, if so directed by the Minister, purchase any and all of the materials or equipment required by the contract from some other supplier or suppliers designated by the Minister, with which the Department of Mines and Resources may have made special arrangements for the supply thereof with respect to priorities in the delivery thereof.

PAYMENTS.

(e) Five copies of all progress claims and summaries of invoices in connection with the work shall be rendered by the Contractor to the Indian Agent.
