2. SUCCESSORS AND ASSIGNS.

This contract shall accrue to the benefit of all and shall be binding upon the heirs, executors, administrators or successors and assigns (subject as hereinafter provided) of the Contractor and the successors of His Majesty; provided that the Contractor shall not be entitled to assign or sublet this contract or any of the work except as herein expressly provided.

3. QUALITY OF WORK.

The work shall be performed by the Contractor using the best materials and finished in the best and most workmanlike manner, and in strict conformity with the contract, and to the complete satisfaction of the Indian Agent and the Minister, and at such places as the Indian Agent shall, from time to time, direct.

4. TIME.

Time shall be deemed to be material and of the essence of this contract.

5. CHANGES IN THE WORK.

The Minister may, through the Indian Agent from time to time, by written instructions or drawings issued to the Contractor, make changes in the work, issue additional instructions, require additional work or direct the omission of work previously ordered, and the provisions of the contract shall apply to all such changes, modifications and additions with the same effect as if they were embodied in the contract plans, drawings and specifications.

Instructions shall be deemed to have been duly given to the Contractor if given to the Superintendent or to a foreman of the Contractor on the work, or if given to the Contractor personally or, if the Contractor is a firm or corporation, to a member of such firm or officer of such corporation.

If there is any change in the work, the Minister shall decide if there has been such a material increase or decrease in the scope of the work so that an adjustment should be made in the Contractor's fee and the Minister's decision on the adjustment to be made shall be final.
6. INDIAN AGENT SOLE JUDGE OF WORK AND MATERIALS.

The Indian Agent shall be the sole judge of the work and material, in respect of both quality and quantity, and his decision on all questions in dispute with regard thereto, or as to the meaning or intention of the contract and as to the meaning or interpretation of the plans, drawings and specifications shall be final, and no work under the contract shall be deemed to have been performed, nor materials or things provided, so as to entitle the Contractor to payment therefor unless and until the Indian Agent is satisfied therewith, as evidenced by his certificate in writing, which certificate shall be a condition precedent to the right of the contractor to be paid therefor; provided that any such decision may be altered or cancelled by the Minister.

7. WORK SUBJECT TO CONTROL OF INDIAN AGENT.

The work shall, in every particular, be under and subject to the control and supervision of the Indian Agent.

8. FOREMAN OF WORKS.

A competent foreman shall be kept on the ground by the Contractor during working hours, to receive the orders of the Indian Agent. Such foreman shall be considered as the lawful representative of the Contractor and shall carry out all requisitions and instructions of the Indian Agent.

9. DEFECTIVE WORK OR MATERIAL.

Should the Contractor use or employ or intend to use or employ, any material, plant, tools equipment, articles or things, which, in the opinion of the Indian Agent, are not in accordance with the provisions of the contract, or are in any way unsuitable for the work, or any part thereof, or should the Indian Agent consider that any work is for any reason, improperly, defectively, or insufficiently executed or performed, the Indian Agent may order the Contractor to remove the same, and to use and employ proper material, plant, tools, equipment, articles and things or to properly re-execute and perform such work, as the case may be, and thereupon the Contractor shall immediately comply with such orders and if the Contractor fails to comply with such orders within twenty-four hours the Indian Agent may, at any time thereafter, execute or cause to be executed the orders so given.

10. CONSUMABLE TOOLS, MATERIALS AND SUPPLIES.

All usable tools (other than tools customarily provided by tradesmen) and all consumable materials and supplies left over after the completion of the work shall, if the Minister so desires, be taken over and be paid for by the Contractor at a fair and reasonable price to be determined by the Minister.

11. WORK NOT COMPRISED IN CONTRACT.

His Majesty may, at any time, without payment therefor, send and employ on, in and about the work other contractors, and workmen, with such horses, machinery, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles and things as the Indian Agent may deem necessary to do any work not comprised in the contract, and the Contractor shall afford them all reasonable facilities, to the satisfaction of the Indian Agent, for doing such work, the work of the Contractor being interfered with as little as the Indian Agent may deem practicable.
The taking of possession of the whole or any part of the work of the Contractor for such purpose shall not be deemed in acceptance by or on behalf of His Majesty of the whole or any portion of the work comprised in this contract.

12. POWER TO TAKE WORK FROM CONTRACTOR.

In case the Contractor shall make default or delay in commencing, or in diligently executing any of the work or portions thereof to be performed, or that may be ordered under the contract, to the satisfaction of the Indian Agent, the Indian Agent may give a general notice to the Contractor requiring him to put an end to such default or delay, and should such default or delay continue for six days after such notice shall have been given by the Indian Agent to the Contractor, or should the Contractor make default in completion of the work or any portion thereof, within the time limited with respect thereto in or under this contract, or should the Contractor become insolvent or abandon the work or make an assignment of this contract without the consent required or otherwise fail to observe and perform any of the provisions of the contract, then and in any of such cases, the Minister, for and on behalf of His Majesty, and without any further authorization, may take all the work out of the Contractor's hands and may employ such means as he may see fit to complete the work, and in such cases the Contractor shall have no claim for any further payment on account of the fee stipulated to be payable to the Contractor for the speed of work performed, but shall be chargeable with and shall remain liable for all loss and damage which may be suffered by His Majesty by reason of such default, or delay, or the non-completion by the Contractor of the work, and all horses, machinery, tools, plant and equipment, and all rights proprietary or otherwise, licences, powers and privileges, whether relating to or affecting real estate or personal property, acquired, possessed or provided by the Contractor for the purposes of the work, or by the Indian Agent under the provision of the contract may be used, exercised and enjoyed by His Majesty, for the purpose of carrying out the work as fully to all intents and purposes as they might theretofore have been used, exercised and enjoyed by the Contractor.

13. INSURANCE.

(a) The Contractor, unless otherwise instructed by the Minister shall insure all materials, equipment and the Contractor's plant during transit and at all times during the construction and until the final acceptance of the work and shall keep the same and all buildings and structure being constructed and/or erected insured against loss by fire, in such insurance company or companies and in such amount or amounts as may be approved by the Indian Agent. The policies of such insurance shall be made payable to the interests of the Contractor and His Majesty respectively, appear, and the original policies together with certified copies thereof shall be forwarded to the Indian Affairs Branch; provided that such buildings or structures need not be insured by the Contractor from and after the date of the occupation thereof by His Majesty.

(b) The Contractor shall maintain such insurance as will protect him from claims under the Workmen's Compensation Acts and from any other claims for damages for personal injury, including death, which may arise from his operations under the Contract. Certificates of such insurance shall be forwarded to the Indian Affairs Branch.
and shall be subject to their approval as to adequacy of protection; and the Contractor shall indemnify and save harmless His Majesty from and against all claims and demands, loss, costs, damages, actions suits or other proceedings by whomsoever made, brought or prosecuted in any manner based upon, occasioned by, or attributable to any such death, or injury, or any damage to, or infringement of, any property or right.

14. GOVERNMENT ISSUE

(a) All items comprised in any Government issue supplied to the Contractor for the purposes of the contract shall always be and remain the property of His Majesty and shall be used by the Contractor solely for the purposes of the contract and the Contractor shall account fully to the minister for such Government issue in such manner as the Minister may require.

(b) The Contractor shall be responsible for and shall indemnify His Majesty for all loss or damage of or to any and all such Government issue while on the premises of or in the care or subject to the control of the Contractor and shall at its own expense replace, repair or restore to the complete satisfaction of the Minister any and all such Government issue which may be so lost or damaged; provided that the Contractor shall not be obligated to make good damage caused by reasonable wear and tear or due to causes beyond his control.

15. PRECAUTIONS AGAINST FIRE

The Contractor shall take special precautions to prevent fire occurring in or about the work, and shall observe and comply with all laws and regulations in force respecting fires, and with all regulations and instructions made and given from time to time during construction, by the Indian Agent with respect to fires and the prevention and extinguishing of fires.

16. ASSIGNMENTS

The Contractor shall not assign or sublet the contract without the written consent of the Minister first obtained; provided however, that (unless, in any case, the Minister objects thereto and subject also as herein provided) the Contractor may sublet such portions of the work herein contracted for as is customary and usual in the construction of such work, but His Majesty shall not in any way be held liable for the payment of any moneys due to any sub-contractor, and the Contractor shall be held responsible for the proper performance of every portion of the work herein contracted for.

17. SUB-CONTRACTORS

The Contractor shall, before entering into any sub-contracts for work or materials, notify the Indian Agent in writing of the names of all such proposed sub-contractors and the terms and conditions of such sub-contracts and shall not enter into any such sub-contracts without obtaining the approval of the Indian Agent thereto.

The Indian Agent may, on request, furnish to any sub-contractor wherever practicable, evidence of the amounts certified to on his account.

The Contractor agrees to bind every sub-contractor by the terms of the General Conditions, Drawings and Specifications, as far as applicable to his work.
18. MEMBER OF H. OF C. NOT TO BENEFIT

No member of the House of Commons of Canada shall be admitted to any share or part of the contract, or to any benefit to arise therefrom.

19. ACCOUNTS

The Contractor shall keep proper accounts and records in such form and detail as shall be satisfactory to the Minister of the cost to the Contractor of the work and the invoices, receipts and vouchers relating thereto, and such accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers shall at all times be open to audit and inspection by the Minister or his authorized representatives (who may make copies thereof and take extracts therefrom) and the Contractor shall afford all proper facilities for such audits and inspections and shall furnish the Minister and his authorized representative with all such information as he or they may from time to time require with reference to such accounts, invoices, receipts and vouchers. If any part of the work is performed by an allied firm (as defined herein) the Contractor shall also cause such allied firms to keep similar accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers with respect to the cost of the work performed by such allied firm and to permit the same to be inspected and audited by the authorized representatives of the Minister. The Contractor shall cause all such accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers as aforesaid to be preserved and kept available for audit and inspection at any time and from time to time until the expiration of five (5) years from the date of the termination of the work.

20. WORK TO BE FREE FROM ALL ENCUMBRANCES

Before making any payment on any progress or final estimate the Minister may require the Contractor to furnish evidence that all work performed, and material supplied and all structures built for which payment is being made are free and clear from all lawful claims or liens under any law for labour, workmanship, materials or otherwise; the Contractor shall indemnify and hold harmless His Majesty from and against any and all kinds of claims or liens accruing from labour and services performed and material furnished or otherwise, and any of the same in or about the works.

21. PATENT CLAIMS AND ROYALTIES

(a) His Majesty shall indemnify the Contractor against all actions, claims or proceedings for infringement of any patent or industrial design rights or of any alleged patent or industrial design rights (hereinafter referred to as "patent rights") in carrying out his contract, and for royalties or other payments which may be payable in connection with any such patent rights (including any amounts properly payable by the Contractor to any of its sub-contractors pursuant to any similar covenant of indemnity given by the Contractor to any sub-contractor), in respect of anything the model, plan or design of which shall have been provided by or on behalf of His Majesty, but this indemnity shall apply to this contract only.

(b) Save and except as set forth in sub-section (a) of this section, the Contractor shall indemnify His Majesty against all actions, claims or proceedings for infringement of any patent rights and for royalties or other payments which may be payable in connection with any such patent rights in carrying out this contract.
(c) Before making any payments with respect to any patent rights, the Contractor shall supply to the Minister a statement showing all payments and claims for payment by way of royalties or otherwise which the Contractor or any of its sub-contractors will or may be obligated to make or proposes to make to the owner or holder of any patent rights in connection with this contract, and the basis thereof and the parties to whom the same are payable, and shall from time to time promptly advise the Minister of any and all claims or arrangements made or proposed, which would or might result in further or different payments being made by the Contractor or any of its sub-contractors by way of royalties or otherwise as aforesaid.

(d) If and when the Minister shall so direct, the Contractor shall make no payment by way of royalties or otherwise with respect to any patent rights referred to in any statement furnished by the Contractor as provided in sub-section (c) of this section, except with the consent of the Minister and subject to such conditions as the Minister may impose and from and after the giving of any such direction by the Minister, His Majesty shall indemnify the Contractor against any action, claim or proceeding for infringement of the patent rights covered by such direction or for non-payment of royalties or other payments in respect thereof.

22. SANITATION

The Contractor shall comply with, and the work shall be carried on subject to all regulations made by any lawful authority and applicable to said work, and all orders given by the Indian Agent with respect to sanitation or preservation of health on the work. The Contractor shall make adequate arrangements, to the satisfaction of the Indian Agent, for the medical and sanitary supervision of all his employees.

23. INDIAN AGENT'S MARKS

The Contractor shall protect, and shall not remove or destroy, or permit to be removed or destroyed, the stakes, buoys and other marks placed on or about the said work by the Indian Agent or his assistants, and shall furnish the necessary assistance to correct or replace any stake, buoy or mark which through any cause may have been removed or destroyed.

24. NOTICES

Any notice, order, direction or other communication given to the Contractor under any of the provisions of this contract shall be sufficiently given if delivered to the Contractor personally, or to his foreman, or left at the Contractor's office, or mailed at any post office to the Contractor or foreman addressed to the address mentioned in the contract, or to the Contractor's last known place of business or residence.

25. PROGRESS MEASUREMENTS AND CERTIFICATES NOT BINDING

The progress measurements and progress certificates shall not in any respect be taken as binding upon the Indian Agent or as final measurements or as fixing final amounts; they are to be subject to the revision of the Indian Agent in making up his final certificate, and they shall not in any respect be taken as an acceptance of the work or as a release of the Contractor from responsibility in respect thereof.
26. **PROTECTION OF WORK**

The Contract and all information issued in connection therewith are confidential and their use must be strictly confined to the work and to the purpose of the Contract; and particulars contained therein; and other matter issued in connection therewith, must not be disclosed to unauthorized persons.

The Contractor shall at all times take and cause to be taken all reasonable measures, for the protection of the work against espionage and sabotage, and on the order of the Minister shall dispense with the services of any person employed in, about or upon the work or cause the same to be dispensed with. The Minister shall at all times through such agency as he may see fit be enabled to maintain order about the premises where the work or any part thereof is being carried on such police or other protective force as in the opinion of the Minister may be advisable.

27. **CANADIAN WORK AND MATERIALS**

To the full extent that the same are procurable, only Canadian labour, parts and materials (unless otherwise agreed by the Minister) shall be used in connection with the work.

27a. **EMPLOYMENT OF EX-SERVICE MEN**

In engaging labour for the work contemplated by this contract, either from the National Employment Service or from Trade Unions with which the contractor has collective agreements, the contractor shall specify that preference shall be given to competent and available ex-service men.

The contractor shall maintain and keep available for inspection by the Minister a record of the names and addresses of ex-service men employed, together with a record of the steps taken to implement this requirement.

28. **SALARIES**

The salaries payable to engineers, superintendents, draftsmen and foremen shall only be such as shall be approved by the Minister.

29. **TERMINATION**

(a) Notwithstanding anything in this contract contained the Minister may, by giving notice to the Contractor, terminate the contract (save and except the provisions of this section and of Section 19 of these general conditions) as regards all or any part or parts of the work or works not theretofore completed. Upon such notice being given, the Contractor shall cease work (including the procuring of materials for the fulfilment of the contract) in accordance with and to the extent specified in such notice but shall proceed with all reasonable speed to complete such part or parts (if any) of the work or works as are by the terms of such notice to be completed and shall thereafter proceed with all reasonable speed to complete up to such time end/or stage as may be specified in the notice any part or parts of the work or works as referred by such notice. The Minister may, at any time, or from time to time give one or more additional notices with respect to any or all parts of the work which remain to be completed after the giving of any previous notice or notices.

(b) All work completed by the Contractor under or pursuant to the provisions of the contract before or after the giving of any notice, subject to acceptance by His Majesty in accordance with the provisions of the contract, shall be paid for on the basis provided in the agreement (the Contractor being allowed such fraction of his
stipulated fee as shall be proportionate to the amount of the work theretofore completed) and the Contractor shall be entitled to be reimbursed the actual cost to the contractor of work not completed under or pursuant to the provisions of this contract and/or any notice given pursuant thereto plus a fair and reasonable profit in respect of work done thereon, provided that no reimbursement shall be made for materials which have been or may be rejected after inspection as not complying with the terms and conditions of this contract and the specifications.

(c) In the event that the Contractor and the Minister are unable to agree upon the amount in respect of which the Contractor is entitled to be reimbursed as aforesaid, the matter shall be referred to the Exchequer Court.

(d) Whenever practicable the Contractor shall procure materials required for the performance of the contract on terms that will enable it to terminate any contracts entered into by the Contractor upon conditions and terms similar or equivalent to those herein provided in respect to termination by the Minister and the giving of a notice or notices as aforesaid; and generally the Contractor shall co-operate with His Majesty and the Minister and do everything reasonably within its power at all times to minimize and reduce the amount of His Majesty's obligations under the provisions of this section.

(e) Upon reimbursement being made to the Contractor as herein provided, title to the materials and/or work in progress in respect of which such reimbursement is made shall pass to and vest in His Majesty (the Contractor hereby agreeing to execute and deliver all requisite instruments by way of further assurance) and such materials and/or work in progress shall be delivered to the order of the Minister, but the materials thus taken over will in no case be in excess of what would have been required for performing the contract in full if no notice had been given under the provisions hereof.

(f) If it is established to the satisfaction of the Minister by the Contractor that by reason of any action taken by the Minister under the provisions of this section exceptional hardship has resulted to the Contractor then the Minister may, notwithstanding any other provisions of this section, in his absolute discretion grant such allowance (not to include in any case, however, any allowance or compensation for loss of profit) to the Contractor as, in the opinion of the Minister is warranted by the circumstances.

(g) Any action, decision or determination by the Minister under the provisions of this section shall be final and binding upon the Contractor.

(h) The Contractor shall have no claim for damages, compensation loss of profit, allowance or otherwise by reason of or directly or indirectly arising out of any action taken or notice given by the Minister under or pursuant to the provisions of this section except as and to the extent in this section expressly provided.

(i) The right of termination and of giving notice hereinbefore provided shall be in addition to and not in substitution for any other right possessed by His Majesty and/or the Minister.

The Contractor shall comply with and be subject to all the terms and conditions of the Labour Conditions (if any) referred to in the agreement and to all variations and modifications thereof that may at any time be enacted or brought into force during the continuance of the contract.

Agreement dated September 29, 1947, between The Minister of Mines and Resources and George V. Hannah authorized the construction of a one room school and teacher's residence on the Mississauga Indian Reserve, at cost of the work plus a Fee of $1,000.00.

It is noted that in a letter from our Department dated Ottawa September 23, 1947 the estimated cost is quoted as being $6,000.00.

SUPERVISION

The work was supervised by Mr. R.P.G. Laurence, Indian Agent, Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario. Mr. Laurence had authority to approve all charges (see letter dated Ottawa September 23, 1947) and has signed all vouchers, payrolls and Form 1064, indicating his approval.

DISTRIBUTION OF EXPENDITURES

Labour
Wages $5,726.01
Vacation Pay 94.87
Workmen's Compensation Insurance 157.88
Unemployment Insurance 30.98
P.L. & P.D. Insurance 29.02 $6,038.08

Material and Expenses
Miscellaneous Expenses 7,062.16
Room Rent 378.00
Subcontracts 956.28
Contractor's Expenditures $14,460.47
Garbage 675.00
Fee 1,000.00
Total Cost $16,158.47

PROGRESS CLAIMS

Recovery of expenditures on claims 1 - 4 was received by means of interim progress certificates.

RATES

Wage rates were approved by the Indian Agent. Daily labour reports were test-checked to payrolls about 95% and the compilation of the payrolls test-checked approximately 95%.

WORKMEN'S COMPENSATION INSURANCE

Workmen's Compensation Insurance was charged at the rate of 5¢. This has been established as the actual rate for 1947. The provisional rate for 1948 was reduced to 2.75¢, and attached to claim 5 as a credit of $5.30 to cover this reduction. This credit did not cover insurance paid on Vacation Pay, but as this only amounted to .66 no correction was made.
Credit is also attached amounting to $11.61 covering rebate of insurance on excess wages.

Attached to this final report is a letter from the Workmen's Compensation Board stating the contractor is in good standing.

This charge is in accordance with the contract.

The contractor made some doors, sash and cupboards in his shop. I have verified the cost by examination of the work sheets.

Receiving reports covering receipt of material at the project were not kept by the contractor. We have therefore been unable to verify the quantities of material.

Computations, extensions and additions of vouchers were tested checked approximately 95%.

Room rent of $378.00 and board of $351.24 were paid by the contractor for room and board for his employees. These charges were approved by the Indian Agent.

Subcontracts (2) consist of plumbing and installation of a furnace. These charges are approved by the Indian Agent. Attached to the final claim is a statutory declaration from the subcontractor who installed the furnace. We did not require statutory declaration from the plumber as more than 50 days have elapsed since he submitted his final claim.

Most of the materials had to be trucked from Sault Ste. Marie to the site and the Indian Agent approved a rate of $15.00 a trip. This charge amounts to $675.00.

The fee claimed of $1,000.00 is in accordance with the contract.

The Indian Agent states that no inventories remain. Extra material was returned and credited in progress claims.

Wages and suppliers' invoices were paid by cheque. Paid cheques returned from the bank were examined, and I have ascertained that all charges have been paid with the exception of one outstanding cheque:

Albert Coleman Claim #5 Invoice Dec. 10, 1947 $6.45.

I hereby certify that I have made an examination of the accounts and records of George V. Hannah insofar as they pertain to this contract, and I have received the information requested, and that subject to the comments of this report, the total cost of the work as shown by the above accounts and records, is $16,135.47 including payment to the contractor of $675.00 for cartage and his fee of $1,000.00.

Ottawa, 13th November, 1908.

His Excellency

The Governor General in Council.

The undersigned begs to report that a resolution was passed in July last by the Mississagi River Band of Indians in favour of charging to their capital the cost of an addition which was found advisable to make to the school-house on their reserve, in the District of Algoma.

The total cost of the work amounts to $216.53, and as the said work is in the nature of a permanent improvement and properly represents capital, the undersigned would recommend that, under the provisions of Section 90 of the Indian Act, authority be given for the expenditure thereon of the above mentioned sum from the capital at the credit of the Mississagi River Band, which amounts to $7,504.29.

Sir,

L. Yelland, Manager of The Hudson's Bay Co., Motet has written me regarding opening a school there. He says that there are seventeen Indian children of school age and he has three of his skin that he would like to lend.

A new building would not be necessary as I understand that there is a house that could be used after making a few alterations. Motet is about thirty miles east of the Pic River Reserve.

Regarding Indian Education I think that a farm should be connected with the school on every Reserve. It is apparently impossible to teach the old people to farm but should be easy to teach the young.

The teachers at St. Joseph's Boarding School tell me that most of their pupils forget what was learned at school just as soon as they get back on the Reserve. I know that the boys and girls on the Fort William Reserve are growing up without any ambition except perhaps to do as their parents do.

Yours truly,

April 26th, 1915.

Dear Sir -

I have your letter of the 14th instant, with reference to the establishment of a school for the Indians at Montizambert. Sir:

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of Inspector Greening's report regarding his inspection of the Mobert Indian Day School on the 22nd ultimo.

This report reads, in part, as follows:

"The difficulty is that the Indians at Mobert have lost interest in the school. The Chief called to see me and told me that, in spite of his best endeavours, he was unable to get the children to school. Many of the families, he said, had moved from Mobert rather than send their children to school there. At my visit in May, there were only four children present, so that I was unable to form any estimate of the work that had been done during the year. At this visit, as will be seen in another part of this report, there were seven pupils present. The Chief says that it is the boys who show the greatest reluctance to going to school. I would imagine that the pupils at this school are not so well advanced as they were when Miss St. Louis left; this condition, no doubt, being the result of lack of interest and poor attendance. Unless the available children can be got to attend school, the work being done hardly warrants the expenditure being made."

"The Reserve Constable (Bonanish by name, I believe) has done very little to assist the teacher in securing attendance. Indeed, he is one of those who have left the reserve."

The Department would appreciate receiving from you a full report regarding the conditions at Mobert. You might let me know the approximate number of children of school age at that point and what steps you have taken to secure a more regular attendance.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie.
Secretary.

J. G. Burk, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Fort Arthur, Ont.

Ottawa, September 7, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, enclosing an application from Miss Josephine D. Scott for the position as teacher of the Mobert Indian Day School.

In reply I have to inform you that the appointment of Miss Scott is approved, to begin duties October 1st, next. Miss Scott's qualifications have not been stated, and I would request that you furnish full information regarding same. You might also state her age and previous teaching experience. The salary allowed her would depend upon the qualifications which she possesses. When we have this information, you will be advised as to the salary she will be allowed.

I have also your letter regarding Miss V. Hamer, former teacher at the Sand Point Indian Day School. At the present time there is no vacancy to which she could be appointed. She will be kept in mind, however, and will be favourably considered for appointment to the first suitable vacancy that occurs.

Sept., 27th, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter 9-14-1, of the 23rd inst. relative to the opening of a temporary school for the benefit of 35 Indian children on the Mobert Reserve, and in reply beg to advise I have recently returned from the Reserve and find I will be able to rent a suitable building for classroom work.

Referring to the desks, I beg to report I have consulted a local lumber manufacturing company, who advised me they would be able to construct suitable benches and tables at a very reasonable figure. The cost of desks, tables, stoves, furniture, etc. will be approximately $300.00.

With reference to obtaining the services of a teacher for this school, I wish to report I recently received a letter from a teacher living in the vicinity of the Reserve. I have communicated with the teacher advising her to send in her application immediately.

I trust this is satisfactory.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Ottawa, October 3rd, 1929.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, relative to the opening of a temporary school for the benefit of the Indian children on the Mobert Reserve. In this connection, it is noted that you will be able to rent a suitable building to carry on the classroom work. The Department will approve of your incurring an expenditure of, approximately, $300., in the fitting up of the building you can obtain for classroom purposes. You should have the benches and tables built locally and you may purchase the stoves, furniture, etc., required, keeping all costs as low as possible. You should complete arrangements to secure the building referred to by you and have same fitted up as soon as possible in order that the school can be opened at an early date. Please forward accounts in duplicate, properly certified, covering all expenditures incurred which, it is hoped, you will be able to keep within the above-authorized amount.

You have not stated the rental that will be charged for the use of the building and I shall be pleased to have this information.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Sir:

I wish to refer to your 210-LD of the 29th ultimo and to inform you that funds are now available for the erection of a combined classroom and teacher's residence at the Mebert Indian Day School. Port Arthur, Ont.,

Sir:

I wish to report I have just received a letter from the Mobert Band, advising the lake water where they obtained their drinking water has recently been condemned.

I would suggest that an inexpensive pump be purchased which could be used for the school children and also the Band. This pump and attachments will cost approximately $10.00 to $15.00.

I have communicated with the Band advising them to dig a well immediately and reported I would communicate with the Department for the necessary authority to purchase a pump.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, June 2, 1930.

Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 29th ultimo, I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase of a pump to be installed in the well which is to be used for the benefit of the pupils of the Mobert Indian Day School and Indians of the Band. It is noted you estimate the cost will not exceed the sum of $15. After you have purchased and forwarded the pump, you should obtain an account, in duplicate, covering the cost. This you should certify in the usual manner and send to the Department for payment.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of September 16th, we can supply you with a 22" School Bell at a price of $32.50, f.o.b. Mobert, which we understand is the nearest Station to King st., which freight is handled.

On looking up the Railway Guide we find there are two places in Ontario by the name of "King"—one not far from Toronto and the other in the Thunder Bay District. We are under the impression that it is this latter place to which you are referring.

The Bell on which we have quoted is made of the highest grade cast steel, possesses a sweet, rich, mellow tone and is of the greatest durability. The price includes mountings. A tolling hammer can be supplied if required, but it would be extra.

In closing we would like to mention that we carry a stock of these Bells, and should we be favored with your order immediate shipment could be made.

Yours very truly,

THE GEO.M. HENDRY CO., Limited.

S/Ms.
Ottawa, September 24, 1930.

Gentlemen:

I have your letter of the 18th instant, quoting the price at which you will supply a 22" school bell for delivery at King, Ont.

In reply I have to say that your quotation is accepted, and I have to request that you will arrange to ship, as soon as possible, addressed to J. G. Burk, Esq., Indian Agent, King, Ont., one school bell, 22" in diameter, with mountings, complete. This should be supplied at the price quoted by you, viz., $32.50 F.O.B. King. We will not require a tolling hammer. This bell is for the use of the Mobert Indian Day School. I may say that we were requested to have this bell forwarded to King, Ont., which is the nearest station to the school. King is on the O.P.R., in the Thunder Bay district.

After shipment has been made, please forward your account, in triplicate, covering the cost of the bell to Mr. Burk, whose post office address is Port Arthur, Ont. He is being informed of the order placed with you, and requested, upon receipt of the bell, to certify the account and send it to the Department, when payment will be made.

Yours very truly,

F. H. Paget,
Accountant & Purchasing Agent.

Ottawa, September 24, 1930.

Sir:

In further reference to your letter of the 13th instant, relative to supplying a school bell for the use of the Mohert Indian Day School, I have to inform you that we are today placing an order with the Geo. M. Hendry Co. Ltd., Toronto, to ship, addressed to you, King, Ont., one school bell, 22" in diameter, complete with mountings. The price quoted is $32.50 F.O.B. King.

The above firm have been requested to make early shipment and to forward their account, in triplicate, covering the cost to you. Upon receipt of the bell, you should certify the account and forward same to the Department, in duplicate, retaining one copy on file in your office.

When this bell arrives, you should arrange to have it taken to the school and set up in the tower of the new school building. Should any bell rope or other accessories be required, you may arrange for the purchase of same, and see that the bell is properly installed and placed in good, serviceable condition. It is hoped that this bell will be satisfactory.

Sir:

Confirming the following wire:

"The following wire received from
"Hudson's Bay Company Mobert Day School damaged
"by fire this morning Chief and men saved
"buildings. Come on No. 4 with insurance
"adjustor stop. Leaving immediately for Mobert
"with carpenter detailed report following".

I beg to report I left on the first available
train for Mobert to investigate this fire.

The fire apparently originated
from an over-heated pipe. The pipe did not
fit the pipe hole in the chimney snugly
so the foreman was compelled to fill this
space with concrete. A large piece of
this cement had dried and fallen out leaving
a small space where sparks might have
penetrated. Unfortunately the teacher had
neglected to turn the damper off in the
pipe. The fire started at 4 a.m. during
an exceptionally cold spell and high winds.

I found the teacher suffering
from a nervous shock and extremely worried
about her neglect. I did not reprimand her
at the time as she felt she should resign
at once. I feel that this might have happened
in any case, and as the inspector reports that
she is doing good work would not recommend
that she leave this school.

The approximate cost of the fire
should not exceed $150.00.

A circular letter has been mailed
to all schools in this Agency urging that the
greatest precautions be taken in case of fire.

I regret very much having to report
this fire and trust there will be no other such
instances.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Ottawa, December 15, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 8th instant, furnishing a report on the fire that occurred at the Hobert Indian Day School on the 4th instant. It is noted that the fire was caused through an overheated pipe, and that the damage will not exceed approximately $150.

You may take the necessary steps as soon as possible to have the repairs required carried out. You should see that the pipe is properly installed, and that every precaution is taken to see that fire does not recur from the same cause. The Department does not feel that any blame should be attributed to the teacher. Please keep any costs in carrying out the repairs as low as possible, and, when completed, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, in the usual manner covering the expenditure incurred.

The action taken by you in circularizing the schools is approved, and it is hoped that every precaution will be taken by the teachers and that there will be no other such instances.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Sir:

On my recent visit to the Mobert Day School, I found the following equipment should be purchased for the school:

- 1 frying pan,
- 1 Broom,
- 4 Inexpensive Curtain rods/to replace old rods which collapsed,
- 1 Swede saw,
- 1 dozen Cups,

Miss St. Louis informed me she does not keep the furnace on after 7 in the evening, as she is afraid of fire. She informed me if an inexpensive stove was purchased for the kitchen it would give sufficient heat to heat her residence, and she would also be able to prepare noonday lunches for the school children.

The oil stove is very economical to operate for one person, but if Miss St. Louis allows the furnace to go out directly after school is over, and only operates a kitchen stove for cooking and heating her residence it would be much cheaper to purchase a stove.

A very inexpensive stove could be purchased from Batons, which is a combination heater and cooker, for approximately $23.00.

I would suggest that this stove be purchased for the Mobert School, as it will actually pay for itself in a short time.

Sir:

I beg to draw the Department's attention to requests from school teachers, which are received at this office from time to time for various inexpensive articles, such as, broom, saw blade, panes of glass, wicks for oil stoves, mantles for gasoline lamps, and various other small articles which as a rule, are urgently required at the time.

For example in one month possibly 4 acquisitions from 4 different schools, and the cost of various articles purchased may cost $4.45 as follows:

|                 | Express    | 1        | 1.70 |

Sir:

I beg to draw the Department's attention to conditions on the Mobert Indian Reserve. The Band are just recovering from a very severe epidemic of whooping cough, and influenza has recently developed on this Reserve. It was necessary to send a nurse down to take charge of the severer cases which developed into pneumonia.

The school children are very much undernourished, and the nurse and myself came to the same conclusion we would be well advised to recommend the following supplies for a lunch for the pupils:

10 lbs. Rice,
10 " Oatmeal,
10 " Sugar,
10 " Barley,
10 " Cocoa,

which will cost approximately $3.00.

If the above meets with the Department's approval I would suggest continuing these monthly supplies until the end of April.

An early reply will be appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to report I recently returned from the Movert Indian Day School. After a careful inspection of each home I found 85% of the children are undernourished. The teacher has supplied oatmeal, rice, and barley, also cocoa. She paid for these from her own pocket.

I would strongly recommend an allowance of $12.00 for 3 months, as the children on this Reserve are undernourished and one hot meal would be of great assistance.

I would also recommend purchasing flannelette and wool for sewing classes which will not exceed $10.00. The teacher advised she would mend the children's clothing, teach them how to darn their socks, and make undergarments. Some of the children are running around very poorly clad with the temperature ranging around 40 to 50 below zero. This Reserve is situated a few miles west of White River.

The following supplies are also required for the school: 7 panes of glass, swede saw, blade, 1 axe.

Your obedient servant,

I wish to advise I have just received a letter from Mrs. Prudhomme, teacher at the Mobert School, advising that the furnace in the school needs fixing. Sir:

With reference to previous correspondence in connection with necessary repairs to be made to the Mobert Indian Day School, I beg to report that a survey of the work to be done, before next winter, has been made and we find that it will be necessary to install and supply two new 8" galvanized pipe, one damper in main heating duct in school classroom, one clean out cover for chimney base, install one clean out furnace door and make general repairs to the furnace. The local firm, who made the initial instalment of the furnace have quoted us a price of $114.00 for the work, which includes expenses and labour for the survey made. I would suggest that this work be completed before the end of the school term, so that the teacher will be present while repairs are being made and would be pleased if the Department would authorize this expenditure.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk, Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 8th instant with reference to repairs which you state are required at the Mobert Indian day school. I note that you state that an amount of $114.00 will be required to do the necessary work but a review of the material required appears to show that such a large expenditure would not be necessary.

In preparing our appropriation for the present fiscal year it was only found possible to include an amount of $925.00 for repairs and improvements at the day schools in the Port Arthur Agency. Nearly all of this amount will be required for the new foundation and other repairs at the McIntyre Bay school and the Department is not in a position to authorize heavy expenditure at the other schools in your Agency this year.

Before giving any consideration to the repairs which you state should be made at the Mobert school the Department will await further details from you.

Yours truly,

J.G. Burk, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.

Sir:

Referring to your letter of July 7th, file 9-14-5 in connection with repairs to the furnace at the Mobert Indian Day school, I beg to report I communicated with Mr. Lampshire, of this city, who advised me that the parts can be obtained from the Beach Foundry Ltd., Ottawa, Ont. and I am attaching herewith, list of parts required.

As you will note by previous correspondence the biggest expense in repairing the furnace is the repair parts required. The labor appears to be very reasonable.

In conclusion, I may say that when the school was constructed we did not make provision for stoves, consequently it would be necessary to have a brick layer construct new openings in the chimney, one for a stove in the classroom and one for a stove in the residence, which I believe would be almost as expensive as the repairs to the furnace. Under the existing circumstances I trust that authorization can be obtained for the repairs to the furnace.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk, Indian Agent.

Attention-Supt. of Welfare & Training

Sir:

I beg to report that the drinking water supply at the Mobert Indian Day School is very poor. It is obtained from a small Lake near the school and for the greater part of the year, it is warm and unfit for drinking. After inspecting the school and discussing the matter with the teacher, Mr. Douglas, he reports that the pump can be installed for approximately $10.00 for Indian labour with his assistance.

The Hudson's Bay Co. at that point have a pump, point and piping etc., and will supply same for a total cost of $12.00.

I would be pleased if the Department would authorize this installation.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Purk, Indian Agent.

Attention-Chief, Training Division

Sir:

During my recent inspection tour of the Mobert reservation, Mr. Douglas, teacher of the day school reported his cook stove was almost completely worn out. I found on investigation that the oven was completely burned out and that the stove has been patched up several times and now is beyond repair. I have made several enquiries regarding the cost of these stoves since my return to the city and I find that the cost of a stove will be approximately $40.00.

I would be pleased, therefore, if the Department would advise if authorization can be granted to make this purchase.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk, Indian Agent.
